citation.article-title: Polaribacter gen. nov., with three new species, P. irgensii sp. nov., P. franzmannii sp. nov. and P. filamentus sp. nov., gas vacuolate polar marine bacteria of the Cytophaga-Flavobacterium-Bacteroides group and reclassification of 'Flectobacillus glomeratus' as Polaribacter glomeratus comb. nov.

p.s: Description of Polaribacter irgensii sp. nov.
Polaribacter irgensii (ir.gen'.si.i. irgensii in honour of Roar L. Irgens, American microbiologist and polar researcher who first observed gas vacuolate polar marine bacteria)
Forms long, thin rods or filaments 0.25-0.5 μm in width and 0.8-48 μm long.
Coccoid bodies are often found in most cultures, particularly ageing cultures.
Cells are orange coloured and may be gas vacuolate.
Have polar flagella but motility has never been observed.
This species produces acid from a number of carbohydrates including D-glactose, D-glucose, mannose and glycerol.
It is capable of growth from - 1.5-12°C (17).
Principal fatty acids include 38% 15:0 iso-3-OH, 12% 15:0 iso and 10% 15:0 3-OH when grown on SWCm agar at 10 °C.
Isolated from sea water near the ice edge in Penola Strait on the Antarctic penninsula.
The type strain of this species is strain 23-P (ATCC 700398).
